name.text: Plotting complex numbers on an Argand diagram

questiontext.text:
By dragging the points from the origin, plot the following complex numbers on the Argand diagram below.

(a) \( {@point1x + point1y*i@} \)

(b) \( {@if point2_rad=1 then "" else if integerp(point2_rad) then point2_rad else sconcat("\\sqrt{", point2_rad^2, "}")@} (\cos({@angles[1]@}) + i \sin({@angles[1]@})) \)

(c) \( {@if point3_rad=1 then "" else if integerp(point3_rad) then point3_rad else sconcat("\\sqrt{", point3_rad^2," }")@} \exp({@angles[2]@} i) \)

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

In an Argand diagram, the position of the point along the \(x\)-axis represents the real part of the complex number and the position on the \(y\)-axis represents the imaginary part.


(a) For the first number, we can determine the coordinates of the point directly by extracting the real and imaginary parts of the complex number.
The point then has coordinates \(({@point1x@}, {@point1y@})\)


(b) For the second number, we evaluate the trigonometric functions to write the complex number in a form which is easier to plot on the Argand diagram.

\(\begin{align*} {@if point2_rad=1 then "" else if integerp(point2_rad) then point2_rad else sconcat("\\sqrt{", point2_rad^2, "}")@} (\cos({@angles[1]@}) + i \sin({@angles[1]@})) &= {@ta2[1] + ta2[2]*i@} \end{align*}\)

Then, point then has coordinates \(({@ta2[1]@}, {@ta2[2]@})\)


(c) For the third number, we use Eulerâ€™s formula to write the complex number in a form which is easier to plot on the Argand diagram.

\(\begin{align*} {@if point3_rad=1 then "" else if integerp(point3_rad) then point3_rad else sconcat("\\sqrt{", point3_rad^2," }")@} \exp({@angles[2]@} i) &= {@if point3_rad=1 then "" else if integerp(point3_rad) then point3_rad else sconcat("\\sqrt{", point3_rad^2, "}")@} (\cos({@angles[2]@}) + i \sin({@angles[2]@}) \\ &= {@if point3_rad=1 then "" else if integerp(point3_rad) then point3_rad else sconcat("\\sqrt{", point3_rad^2, "}")@} (({@cos(angles[2]) + sin(angles[2])*i@} )) \\ &= {@ta3[1] + ta3[2]*i@} \end{align*}\)

Then, point then has coordinates \(({@ta3[1]@}, {@ta3[2]@})\)


Plotting these three points, the Argand diagram should be the following.
